claim: The winter in London is cooler than in New York.

supporting.text: London has a maritime climate, which generally results in milder winters compared to New York's continental climate.

attacks.text: London has a maritime climate, which generally results in milder winters compared to New York's continental climate.
New York's proximity to the Atlantic Ocean moderates its winter temperatures, making them less extreme than other continental climates.
Despite being moderated by the ocean, New York still experiences colder winter temperatures on average due to its higher latitude and exposure to Arctic air masses.
The urban heat island effect in New York can artificially raise winter temperatures compared to rural areas, masking the true continental climate influence.

supporting.text: New York experiences colder winter temperatures due to its proximity to colder air masses from the interior of North America.

attacks.text: New York experiences colder winter temperatures due to its proximity to colder air masses from the interior of North America.
London's winters are moderated by the Gulf Stream, which brings warmer oceanic air, making it cooler than New York on average.
The Gulf Stream's influence is overstated; urban heat islands in London may offset some of the warming effects compared to New York.
Urban heat islands primarily affect nighttime temperatures, while daytime winter temperatures still reflect broader climatic influences like the Gulf Stream.

supporting.text: Average winter temperatures in London are higher than those in New York, based on meteorological data.

attacks.text: Average winter temperatures in London are higher than those in New York, based on meteorological data.
New York experiences more extreme cold spells due to continental climate influences, which can make winters feel colder despite similar averages.
London's maritime climate moderates temperature extremes, leading to consistently milder winters compared to New York's more variable conditions.
Urban heat island effects in London may artificially inflate temperature readings compared to less urbanized areas of New York.
Modern meteorological stations account for urban heat effects through standardized measurement protocols and comparative rural station data.

supporting.text: The Gulf Stream moderates London's winter climate, making it warmer than New York at similar latitudes.

attacks.text: The Gulf Stream moderates London's winter climate, making it warmer than New York at similar latitudes.
New York experiences colder winters due to continental air masses from Canada, which are not significantly moderated by oceanic influences like the Gulf Stream.
London's urban heat island effect further amplifies its winter temperatures compared to less urbanized areas at similar latitudes.
The Gulf Stream's influence has weakened in recent years due to climate change, reducing its moderating effect on London's winters.
